segments.text: Hey, how you doing?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I'm sorry.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Thanks.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I know- I know there's nothing I can say that will really help, but--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know.  I just -- I don't know.  It's just weird because you have somebody who's, you know,
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: a major part of your life and then they're gone.  And I don't know.  That's not really -- it's never really happened to me before.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I'm sorry.  It's never easy.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: But, I'm here if there's anything you need.  I mean, you just have to ask.  I know --
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Thanks.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: --it doesn't really do anything.  But--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I just -- it's just not fair.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I know.  It never is.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: How's, um -- how's his parents doing?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I mean, they're, you know, they're upset.  It's like you know, they
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: feel the same way everybody else does.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I mean, what do you want to do?  Do you want to- do you want to talk about it?  Do you-
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: [BREATHING] I mean, there's nothing really to talk about.  He's gone and I'll never see him again.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Well I know it's not a lot of help or anything, but at least you got to know him.  I mean, at least you had the time with him that you did.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I mean, we can be grateful for that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yeah, I don't know.  Sometimes I wish I didn't know him.  So I wouldn't--
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: You feel that way now because you're upset.  But you don't really think that.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: It'll get better.  I know it doesn't help, but it will get better and you will remember all of the good things that you guys had; all of the memories that you have with him that were happy and you'll be grateful for those.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: This is just -- this is a terrible life.  I just don't understand.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Just life, in general?
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I mean, it's just not fair.  Like, I don't know.  Why people -
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: there should just be some sort of rule that people don't die until they're older, 'cause then, at least, it's expected.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I agree.  If I knew how to make that happen, I would certainly help you.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I don't know what to do.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: When's the service? Can- can we help?  Is there anything, I mean--
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I mean, you- you can go.  I don't know.  I don't know what else.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I hope it rains.  Somehow that'll make me feel more comfortable.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: Seems like if the whole world's sad, then it's okay for you to be.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I just wish there was some way to just bring him back to life magically.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I know.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: Just, you know, some thing; some genie. I need to find a genie bottle.
segments.speaker: M

segments.text: I don't have any magic answers.  But,
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I mean, as- as cliche as it is, as long as people who loved him remember him, then it's not a waste, you know.
segments.speaker: F

segments.text: I know.
segments.speaker: M
